item.title: Should You Fight Rogue Mega Slowbro, Camerupt, or Victreebel First in Pokemon Legends Z-A?
item.description:
After they've beaten Absol and learned the secrets of Mega Evolution, Pokemon Legends: Z-A players will be tasked with taking down three more rogue Mega Evolutions. However, they'll be able to choose which order they fight Rogue Mega Slowbro, Camerupt, and Victreebel, and their decision can have a huge impact on how difficult these boss fights are.

Finding the best order to fight Rogue Mega Slowbro, Camerupt, and Victreebel can therefore make the player's life a whole lot easier, while also helping to shorten their Pokemon Legends: Z-A playthrough a little. This guide will help you to decide which of the rogue mega evolutions to fight first and the best order to complete main missions 11, 12, and 13.

The Best Order to Fight Rogue Mega Slowbro, Camerupt, and Victreebel in Pokemon Legends: Z-A

Mega Slowbro

Mega Camerupt

Mega Victreebel

Water/Psychic-type

Fire/Ground-type

Grass/Poison-type

Level 34

Level 34

Level 34

The best order for fighting Rogue Mega Slowbro, Camerupt, and Victreebel will depend on the Pokemon that players have at their disposal, their levels, and whether or not they have the mega stones needed to mega evolve them. That last one is particularly important, as trying to take down a rogue mega evolution without a mega evolution of your own can take an awfully long time. As such, players should make sure that they have a mega evolution that can target one of the rogue mega evolutions' weaknesses before engaging it in battle.

  • Mega Slowbro is weak against Bug , Ghost , Grass , Electric , and Dark -type attacks.
  • Mega Camerupt is weak against Ground and Water -type attacks, with a 4x weakness to Water.
  • Mega Victreebel is weak against Flying , Fire , Psychic , and Ice -type attacks.

Be sure to check your Pokemon's moves before fighting a rogue mega evolution to ensure that you have the strongest possible moveset to target their weaknesses. You can change a Pokemon's attacks via the main menu.

The good news is that AZ gives players a mega stone for their Pokemon Legends: Z-A starter Pokemon just before this decision, so if they've already evolved it into its Stage 2 form, players should base their choice around that. Chikorita users should fight Mega Slowbro first, players who chose Tepig should start with Mega Victreebel, and those who picked Totodile as their starter should head straight for Mega Camerupt. Sadly, this isn't really an option if your starter isn't fully evolved yet, although players needn't worry too much if this is the case.

Regardless of their starter choice, players already have Absol and the Absolite needed to mega evolve it following their exploits in Main Mission 9. Mega Absol is a Dark-type Pokemon, meaning it's super effective against Mega Slowbro. After defeating each rogue mega evolution, players will get the mega stone needed to evolve it, which can then make dealing with the other rogue mega evolutions a lot easier. Mega Slowbro's Water-type attacks are super effective against Mega Camerupt, and Mega Camerupt's Fire-type attacks are strong against Mega Victreebel.

Mega Slowbro's Psychic-type attacks are also super effective against Mega Victreebel, and Mega Victreebel's Grass-type attacks are strong against Mega Slowbro, if players want to tackle the three rogue mega evolutions in a different order.

The Best Order to Fight Mega Slowbro, Camerupt, and Victreebel

  1. Use Mega Absol's Dark-type attacks to beat Rogue Mega Slowbro.
  2. Catch an Alpha Slowbro in Wild Zone 11 or catch a Slowpoke in Wild Zone 10 or 11 and evolve it at level 37.
  3. Use Mega Slowbro's Water-type attacks to beat Rogue Mega Camerupt.
  4. Catch an Alpha Camerupt in Wild Zone 8 or catch a Numel in Wild Zone 8 and evolve it at level 33.
  5. Use Mega Camerupt's Fire-type attacks to beat Rogue Mega Victreebel. Alternatively, players can skip step four and use Mega Slowbro to beat Rogue Mega Victreebel, if they like.

If players are defeated during a fight against a rogue mega evolution, they'll be given the option to continue the fight where they left off, meaning it's possible to persevere using brute force. This isn't really recommended, though, as fights against rogue mega evolutions last significantly longer when you're not targeting weakness with a mega evolution of your own.

Your comment has not been saved

item.title: Monopoly GO: How to Get Scarf King Token & Coffee Signature Dice
item.description:
The Cozy Comforts album has arrived in Monopoly GO , bringing tons of seasonal charm and cozy vibes to your Monopoly board. From new fall-themed stickers to exclusive collectible rewards, this album is all about comfort and class. It’s the perfect seasonal collection to celebrate cozy mornings, autumn colors, and a hot cup of coffee by your side. The most prized rewards this season are the Scarf King Token & Coffee Signature Dice . They’re the perfect collectibles for all Monopoly GO players who love cozy mornings and hot coffee vibes.

How to Get Scarf King Token in Monopoly GO

The Scarf King Token features Mr. M dressed in his elegant winter attire. With a classic top hat, shades, and a fuzzy orange scarf, Mr. M looks super cozy and warm.

If you want to add the Scarf King Token to your Monopoly GO shelves, you’ll need to complete the Cozy Comforts Album once by completing all its sets. This means finding every regular and gold sticker in the collection through packs, trades, and events. You can also use Wild Stickers to fill in any rare or missing spots much faster.

Once you complete the Cozy Comforts album for the first time, you’ll be rewarded with the Scarf King Token along with 15,000 Rolls as a bonus reward. You can equip the token any time from your Monopoly GO shelves and proudly display it on your board.

How to Get Coffee Signature Dice in Monopoly GO

Everyone loves collecting seasonal dice that perfectly match the theme and vibe of their Monopoly GO board. For the Cozy Comforts season, Scopely has introduced an all-new Coffee Signature Dice . With a beautiful design inspired by warm coffee tones and cozy moments, this Monopoly GO dice skin is an absolute must-have for all dedicated collectors.

To get the Coffee Signature Dice, you’ll need to go one step further and complete the Prestige Cozy Comforts Album . The Prestige album unlocks after you’ve finished the Cozy Comforts album the first time. This advanced version features new sets that require collecting all stickers again, including gold and rare ones. It’s a challenging task, but the rewards make it worth every roll.

Once you’ve collected all the stickers in the Prestige sets, you’ll win an additional 15,000 Rolls along with the Coffee Signature Dice.

If you want to complete both albums quickly, make sure to trade duplicates with friends or in sticker trading groups to fill gaps and always participate in special events that reward you with high-tier sticker packs.

1742
8.8 /10

Monopoly Go!

item.title: Most Important Co-Op Games
item.description:
Anyone who grew up in the 80s and 90s, and perhaps even a bit of the early 2000s, knew the joy of local co-op. They may have distinct memories of their first time at home, at a friend’s house, or at the arcade, enjoying a game with a sibling or friend — not as a versus tournament, but as a cooperative experience.

Thanks to new consoles, the Internet, and technology as a whole, co-op is better now than it has ever been before. Anyone from around the world can team up in big games like Borderlands 4 or Diablo 4 online, or even in couch co-op locally. Those games would not be what they are today without these co-op experiences paving the way forward for a specific series of genres.

Double Dragon

Beat ‘Em Ups Are Born

Double Dragon
Beat 'Em Up
Systems
Released
April 22, 1987

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

Powered by
  • Co-Op Options: Two Local

Double Dragon was not the first beat ‘em up game, but it is regarded as the first one to add two-player co-op. For anyone who knows brawlers, this significantly changed the genre forever, and it became a mainstay in arcades starting in the late 80s and throughout the 90s.

Companies tried to outdo the concept constantly, with the perfect example being the X-Men arcade game, which featured six-player co-op. Importance aside, players can still have a good time with the arcade version of Double Dragon , specifically as it is not as broken as the ports like on the NES.

Diablo

Hell Yes!

Diablo
7.0 /10
Released
January 3, 1997

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ // Animated Blood and Gore, Animated Violence
Powered by
  • Co-Op Options: Four Online/LAN

Diablo transformed the top-down action RPG for the better with its transformative loot system. With multiple classes to choose from, four players could connect and explore dungeons together. It’s a bit archaic now compared to its sequels, but the Diablo games would not be where they are without the original. Also, looter RPGs have since blossomed into a genre that many have tried to copy. There has been some success on that front, but Blizzard’s take on the idea will always be number one.

Monster Hunter

Japan Finds A New Passion

Monster Hunter
Action RPG
Systems
Released
September 21, 2004
ESRB
Teen // Blood, Use of Alcohol, Violence
Developer(s)
Capcom

Powered by
  • Co-Op Options: Four Online

Monster Hunter launched on the PlayStation 2 in 2004 and was an immediate hit in Japan, but was a niche action game elsewhere. It was a four-player online action game that was all about hunting boss-like monsters, which was a novel concept that led to Monster Hunter clones.

It started as a phenomenon in Japan between the PS2 version and later portable versions on systems like the PSP and 3DS, but the franchise is now more widely appreciated. That’s the great thing about the series. Each entry seems to be bigger than the last, with the co-op options becoming greater too, as this first entry was a bit limiting on the PS2.

Gears Of War

Bringing Cover To Shooters

Gears of War
8.8 /10
Released
November 7, 2006

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
m
Powered by
  • Co-Op Options: Two Local/Online

Gears of War did a few innovative things for shooters, including adding two-player co-op to the campaign. Beyond the campaign, which was added in each new entry, players could also engage in a five-player co-op match online called Horde Mode. This mode was basically five players trying to survive waves of enemies, a mode that inspired many other multiplayer game types. Finally, the thing that was truly innovative was the cover system, which worked well in any mode and felt great as a third-person shooter.

Rock Band

Battle Of The Bands

Rock Band
Rhythm
Music
Systems
Released
November 20, 2007

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
T
Powered by
  • Co-Op Options: Four Local/Online

Guitar Hero evolved the music genre that remained big in arcades, but Rock Band revolutionized it. The best setup was definitely playing locally with a group of friends and just jamming away on some of the best rock, pop, and metal songs of all time. Players could get on guitar, bass, drums, or the mic and absolutely bring the house down. The third game even got a keyboard controller. The music genre blossomed for a while but eventually died out, but Rock Band is still a definitive part of co-op history.

Left 4 Dead

Horror Is No Longer Just For Solo Players

Left 4 Dead
8.0 /10
Released
November 17, 2008

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
m
Powered by
  • Co-Op Options: Two Local/Four Online

Resident Evil helped establish the horror genre, and for a long time, horror games were a singular experience. Things are often more frightening alone, so it made sense. Left 4 Dead changed that by creating a compelling four-player first-person horror shooter wherein the zombies were fierce and unrelenting.

Couch co-op fans had options too. PC and Xbox 360 players could not get enough, and thanks to this game’s glowing reviews and player count, other horror franchises started to experiment with co-op, including Resident Evil . The co-op horror genre as we know it may not exist without Left 4 Dead .

New Super Mario Bros. Wii

Mario Gets A 4-Up

New Super Mario Bros. Wii
7.8 /10
Released
November 15, 2009

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
e
Powered by
  • Co-Op Options: Four Local

The Mario games started with two players as an option, but it only allowed partners to swap between deaths. When the series made the jump to 3D, the 2D games were dead for ages until the DS revitalized the idea in 2006 with New Super Mario Bros ., which was successful enough to pave the way forward for New Super Mario Bros. Wii .

This was the first mainline Mario game to offer not just two-player co-op, but four-player co-op, and the game sold incredibly well. It wasn’t the first four-player 2D platformer, but its success definitely changed Nintendo. Now, there are a handful of 2D and even 3D Mario co-op games.

Borderlands

The Looter-Shooter Is Born

Borderlands
8.3 /10
Released
October 20, 2009

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
m
Powered by
  • Co-Op Options: Two Local/Four Online

The first Borderlands may not hold up as strongly as its direct sequel or any other entry in the series, as the franchise has evolved greatly since 2009. However, no one can deny the importance of what it did for shooters.

Borderlands added RPG elements such as leveling up and classes via premade characters. It was basically an evolution of the Diablo looter concept, except with wild amounts of guns instead of melee weapons. Four players could team up online for the lengthy campaign, along with splitscreen couch co-op on consoles.

item.title: Grow a Garden: Best Crops Tier List
item.description:
With pets having been added to Roblox 's Grow a Garden , your farmland has gotten a whole new glow-up. Yet, there is a variety of plants you can place there to make it even more beautiful. With every update, the roster keeps growing, and players now have tons of crop options to choose from.

All of them, however, aren't profitable, since some are just temporary plants that vanish after picking, and others regrow but are quite cheap. Thankfully, there are viable options as well, so here's a full tier list explaining all the available crops and which ones are worth investing your Sheckles in.

Updated by Somiya Adrees on October 18, 2025: Grow a Garden now has 130 crops after the 1.28.0 update, including fruits, veggies, flowers, candy, and bone plants. As such, the tier list featured below has been updated to rank all the new ones and the old favorites (except the Gardener Seed Pack ones), allowing players to uncover which ones truly are the best of the best.

Grow a Garden's Best Crops Tier List

The rankings mostly go by how much money a plant makes from its base price . The list also covers every crop added so far, even the ones you can’t get anymore. Since lots of players still have them growing, this list can help you figure out if they're worth keeping or tossing.

If you're unsure how to use the tier list, here's a quick breakdown:

  • S-tier crops bring in the most profit.
  • A-tier crops are still solid, but don’t earn as much as S-tier.
  • B-tier offers a decent Sheckle average.
  • C-tier doesn’t pay much, but it’s a reasonable option for beginners without better crops.
  • D-tier crops aren’t worth planting at all unless you like how they look or need them for an event.

The “Estimated Profit Per Harvest” column shows the ideal amount of money you can get from each harvest. For crops that aren’t multi-harvest, their full profit is listed directly.

All Crops

Tier Ranking

Reasoning

Estimated Profit Per Harvest

Crimson Thorn

S Tier

A new Transcendent Seed, available in the Seed Shop, grants 7 to 8 Thorns, with one valued at 210k Sheckles.

1,470,000 Sheckles

Candy Blossom

S Tier

Another top pick. Delivers 12 Candy Blossom fruits per round, with every one going for over 100k Sheckles.

1,200,000 Sheckles

Maple Resin

S Tier

The transcendent plant from the Fall event that sells a fruit for 190k, usually giving about 6 to 7.

1,140,000 Sheckles

Bone Blossom

S Tier

The best plant right now , blessing you with 4 to 5 fruits per harvest cycle (priced at 200k). It’s neck-and-neck with Candy Blossom, though that depends on how many fruits your Candy Tree ends up growing.

800,000 Sheckles

Cocomango

S Tier

An OP evergreen crop from Sam’s Seed Shop Tier 2. It drops 4 to 5 cocomangos. Think of it like a coconut tree but with mangoes, each worth 180k.

720,000 Sheckles

Evo Apple

S Tier

Though it starts as a single-harvest plant at Tier I, it’s definitely worth grabbing for its Tier IV version, where it starts regrowing and can bring in around 660k Sheckles in profit; each Evo Apple IV sells for 165k.

660,000 Sheckles

Moon Mango

S Tier

Second best to Bone Blossom and Candy Blossom, it’s a multi-harvest crop that spawns 13 to 20 mangoes at a time, each valued at 50k Sheckles.

650,000 Sheckles

Naval Wort

S Tier

A Season Pass seed that blesses 4 Worts, with one priced at 150k in-game money.

600,000 Sheckles

Multitrap

S Tier

A Divine Seed from the Prime Seed Pack, designed like 3 Venus Flytraps growing from one plant (priced at 180k).

540,000 Sheckles

Dragon Pepper

S Tier

Reharvestable fruit that yields 6 fruits per round, each priced at 88,800 Sheckles.

532,800 Sheckles

Fossilight

S Tier

Keeps up with Dragon Pepper in how many fruits it makes, but can't top its value and total earnings (88k each).

528,000 Sheckles

Moon Blossom

S Tier

Grants 8 to 10 flowers, and each one sells for 66k.

528,000 Sheckles

Inferno Quince

S Tier

Like grape, it has a long stem where 4 Quinces grow each cycle, with one worth 130k in-game currency.

520,000 Sheckles

Acorn

S Tier

A super rare divine seed from the Nutty Chest that yields 4 Acorns (123k each).

492,492 Sheckles

Cyclamen

S Tier

A divine seed found in the Skyroot Chest that grows into 5 flowers.

475,000 Sheckles

Weeping Branch

S Tier

Spawns a huge tree with 3 to 4 long scary branches. Each unit gives 155k. It also has a passive ability that blesses nearby plants with Evo mutations, with the third mutation having a 50x multiplier.

465,000 Sheckles

Elephant Ears

S Tier

Yields 6 fruits per harvest, each selling for 77k.

462,000 Sheckles

Poison Apple

S Tier

A Halloween Market exclusive crop that grows 4 to 5 Poison Apples on the tree, each worth 111k.

444,444 Sheckles

Giant Pinecone

S Tier

Not as profitable as Fossilight and Dragon Pepper, it yields 6 fruits worth 72k each.

432,000 Sheckles

Blood Orange

S Tier

This spooky seed is worth a lot of Candy Corns. It gives 3 harvests, and each sells for 140k.

420,000 Sheckles

Great Pumpkin

S Tier

A multi-harvest crop and the first in GaG to give plants the Ghostly mutation (25x multiplier).

180,000 Sheckles

Sugar Apple

A Tier

Better than Moon Blossom, Hive Fruit, and Beanstalk, but not as valuable as Dragon Pepper and Elephant Ears. Grows 8 apples at once, each selling for 48k Sheckles.

384,000 Sheckles

Tranquil Bloom

A Tier

One of the few plants with a high selling value, 4 blooms at 93k a pop.

372,000 Sheckles

Potato

A Tier

It’s a small plant with flowers on top, but it drops 4 potatoes, each worth about 90k base value.

360,000 Sheckles

Brussels Sprout

A Tier

You’ll get 3 Brussels Sprouts from this crop, each selling for 120k. Not a bad choice from Sam’s Seed Shop Tier 2.

360,000 Sheckles

Firewell

A Tier

The Divine seed from the Fall Seed Pack that produces 2 to 3 Firewells, each valued at 112,111. Its design resembles fallen leaves but can also grow glowing fruits.

336,336 Sheckles

Golden Peach

A Tier

A valuable peach crop that gives 4 glowing peaches, with a base price of 88k for one.

325,000 Sheckles

Poseidon Plant

A Tier

A bright, lovely fruit that grows in 5 and sells for 65k.

325,000 Sheckles

Candy Cornflower

A Tier

From the 1.28.0 update, this is an upgraded version of corn. It’s reharvestable, and the tree grows about 7 to 8 cornflowers (44k each).

311,108 Sheckles

Hive Fruit

A Tier

It provides 5 fruits at once, each worth around 62k Sheckles.

310,000 Sheckles

Beanstalk

A Tier

Beanstalk keeps growing back after each cycle, letting you collect up to 11 at a time, each selling for 28k.

308,000 Sheckles

Pecan

A Tier

A premium seed introduced in the 1.26.0 update. Its single fruit sells for 100k.

300,000 Sheckles

Mangrove

A Tier

A plant with reddish-brown or pale leaves that grows 3 to 4 propagule fruits shaped like long stick-like pods, sold for 100k.

300,000 Sheckles

Traveler's Fruit

A Tier

This crop from the Mega Harvest update yields 5 fruits per harvest, with each fruit selling for 59k.

295,000 Sheckles

Auburn Pine

A Tier

A mythical seed from Fall Event Part 2 that grows into a big tree with 4 auburn pines hanging from it each cycle (one for 73,555 Sheckles).

294,220 Sheckles

Elder Strawberry

A Tier

Not your average berry bush, pulls in 3 to 4 strawberries per round, and they're 90k a pop.

270,000 Sheckles

Spiked Mango

A Tier

Makes 4 to 5 thorny spiked mangoes, each with a good base value of 67,500 Sheckles.

270,000 Sheckles

Grand Tomato

A Tier

Like Elder Strawberry gives around 3 to 4 tomatoes, each going for about 88k.

268,000 Sheckles

Seer Vine

A Tier

A spooky seed that produces eye-shaped fruit, is reharvestable, and sells for 88k each.

266,664 Sheckles

Lily of the Valley

A Tier

With 5 flowers popping up per harvest, Lily of the Valley can cash in big, with each bloom selling for up to 49k.

245,600 Sheckles

Nectarine

A Tier

Grants 5 fruits at once, with each selling for nearly 48k Sheckles.

240,000 Sheckles

Maple Apple

A Tier

About 3 to 5 Maple Apples pop out per harvest, each selling for 77,777 Sheckles.

233,331 Sheckles

Bitter Melon

A Tier

The best plant from the Connoisseur Event (1.18.0 update), it nourishes into 3 to 4 melons that sell for 77k each.

231,000 Sheckles

Gleamroot

A Tier

A mythical plant that spawns three greenish crops, each worth 75k Sheckles.

225,000 Sheckles

Mummy's Hand

A Tier

As expected for a Halloween seed, it grows into a spooky plant wrapped in cloth strips. Two roots appear at a time, shaped like mummy hands (111k/unit).

222,222 Sheckles

Firefly Fern

A Tier

Offers stronger returns than Burning Bud after its nerf (three ferns per round at 72k base value).

216,000 Sheckles

Serenity

A Tier

Around seven flowers bloom on the plant, and one of them is priced at 30k.

210,000 Sheckles

Guanabana

A Tier

The Guanabana crop spawns a minimum of 3 fruits, with each one selling for 70k.

210,320 Sheckles

Grand Volcania

A Tier

Produces 3 flowers at once, and each one sells for 70k Sheckles.

210,000 Sheckles

Rosy Delight

A Tier

A multi-harvest crop that gives 3 roses, each valued at 69k.

207,000 Sheckles

Parasol Flower

A Tier

Offers good value despite being a single-harvest plant.

200,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Mandrone Berry

A Tier

Another berry plant introduced in the 1.24.0 update, which matures into 3 fruits.

195,000 Sheckles

Canary Melon

A Tier

A rare melon plant that comes after Bitter Melon in value, bearing 4 fruits that sell for 65,000 Sheckles a unit.

195,000 Sheckles

Persimmon

A Tier

A legendary seed from the Nutty Chest that grows into a tree, producing 3 Persimmons.

180,000 Sheckles

Wispwing

A Tier

Like other multi-harvest plants that only give 1 fruit per cycle, Wiswing turns into a butterfly-like crop. It’s beautiful to look at, carries a solid base value, and is great for stacking mutations.

180,000 Sheckles

Badlands Pepper

A Tier

Food-type plant that produces 4 peppers, each with an average selling value of 45k.

180,000 Sheckles

Evo Blueberry

A Tier

Once it reaches Tier IV, the plant becomes multi-harvest and pushes out 3 blueberries, each with a market price of 60k.

180,000 Sheckles

Nectar Thorn

A Tier

Better to cultivate than any of the A-tier flower plants, since it’s a permanent crop and produces 4 flowers per harvest, with each being worth 44k Sheckles.

176,000 Sheckles

Amberheart

A Tier

Like some Prismatics and Divines, it spawns a single fruit but isn’t a one-time plant.

175,000 Sheckles

Romanesco

A Tier

A new Seed Shop prismatic crop that, like Ember Lily, gives only one yield.

166,000 Sheckles

Amber Spine

A Tier

More profitable than Sunflower; it blesses 3 spines, selling for 55k each.

165,000 Sheckles

Sunflower

A Tier

Reproduces many sunflowers worth 160k, but only 1 grows at a time (better than Mushroom or Bendboo).

160,000 Sheckles

Bendboo

A Tier

An upgraded Bamboo variant with a whopping 155k Sheckle value.

155,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Mushroom

A Tier

One-time plant, but sells for 151k. Its mutation is wild for profit.

151,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Zen Rocks

A Tier

A one-use plant from the Zen update that doesn’t top the past update's Parasol Flower in selling price.

150,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Boneboo

B Tier

Just a one-shot plant; beats Bamboo, but doesn’t top Bendboo.

141,141 Sheckles (One-time)

Wisp Flower

B Tier

A light pink plant that looks pretty but triggers two scary flowers to sprout (70k/unit).

140,000 Sheckles

Evo Pumpkin

B Tier

A seed meant to evolve. Its final form (Evo Pumpkin IV) is multi-harvest and yields two pumpkins, each selling for 70k.

140,000 Sheckles

Burning Bud

B Tier

A Prismatic seed from the Prehistoric update, it regrows and gives 2 buds at a time with a 70k base value.

140,000 Sheckles

Lingonberry

B Tier

You’ll get 4 berries from it, each worth 35k. It's pretty close to Burning Bud in terms of profit.

140,000 Sheckles

Butternut Squash

B Tier

A food-type crop from the 1.18.0 update that grows about 4 squashes, each selling for around 35k according to the in-game market value.

140,000 Sheckles

Duskpuff

B Tier

A brown mushroom-looking plant from the Sprout Seed Pack that gives 4 Duskpuffs, one going at 35k.

140,000 Sheckles

Spirit Flower

B Tier

It usually gives one flower, but if your plant has three studs, it can produce three, pushing it to S tier with a base profit of around 400k.

135,000 Sheckles

Soft Sunshine

B Tier

Leafy flower-type plant that regrows up to three flowers, one for 45k Sheckles.

135,000 Sheckles

Torchflare

B Tier

A mythical seed from the Fall Seed Pack that usually gives one Torchlight, but can yield up to two if you're lucky, bringing the total profit to 132k (sells for 66,250 each).

132,500 Sheckles

Cocovine

B Tier

Similar to Dragon Pepper, but it drops 2 to 6 fruits at a time, with each being worth 66k Sheckles.

132,000 Sheckles

Lucky Bamboo

B Tier

This is the first bamboo-like plant, and it gives you 2 to 4 Bamboos, each going for about 65k.

130,000 Sheckles

Meyer Lemon

B Tier

The first proper lemon plant. It grows four lemons on the tree each time (more if there’s room), and each lemon sells for 32k.

128,000 Sheckles

Pyracantha

B Tier

A prickly plant that produces 3 fruits, each valued at 42k.

126,000 Sheckles

Enkaku

B Tier

You can harvest 2 to 3 Enkakus in one round, with the average value of one at 62k.

124,000 Sheckles

Aurora Vine

B Tier

It’s a good-looking crop with purple vines, crowned by the aurora plant on top.

120,000 Sheckles

Taro Flower

B Tier

Grants just one flower worth over 120k, then disappears from the garden completely.

120,000 Sheckles (One-time)

King Cabbage

B Tier

A more viable option than Taro Flower, as it produces one veggie after each pick, unlike pure one-time fruits.

120,000 Sheckles

Princess Thorn

B Tier

An event-based multi-harvest plant that produces one prickly crop at a time.

111,000 Sheckles

Kniphofia

B Tier

Similar to Princess Thorn in both price and how it’s harvested.

110,000 Sheckles

Snaparino Beanarini

B Tier

One of the few crops from the 1.20.0 update that’s actually valuable in terms of Sheckles. Yields around three Beanarini on average, each selling for 35k.

105,000 Sheckles

Speargrass

B Tier

This legendary flower plant from Fall Event Part 2 produces two units, each worth 51k.

102,000 Sheckles

Aetherfruit

B Tier

A magic crop that usually gives 1, but can yield up to 3 crystal-like fruits depending on its shape.

100,000 Sheckles

Tall Asparagus

B Tier

Multi-Harvest plant but gives you 1 Asparagus in one harvest cycle.

100,000 Sheckles

Crown Melon

B Tier

Currently priced at 50k, it drops 2 melons.

100,000 Sheckles

Honeysuckle

B Tier

Just like Lumira but with a better selling value: 100k Sheckles.

100,000 Sheckles

Mangosteen

B Tier

A leafy plant that sprouts 2 fruits, usually going for around 50,000 Sheckles.

100,000 Sheckles

Sakura Bush

B Tier

Yields 3 to 6 flowers per harvest, each going for 28,575 Sheckles

85,725 Sheckles

Corpse Flower

B Tier

A Legendary Seed from the Prime Seed Pack that blesses a single fruit but is multi-harvest.

85,000 Sheckles

Lumira

B Tier

Although reharvestable, it grows only 1 plant each round, worth 85k Sheckles. With the sprinkler glitch and the right mutations, it can make you billions.

85,000 Sheckles

Venus Fly Trap

B Tier

Makes a lot, and each trap is worth 85k.

85,000 Sheckles

Lightshoot

B Tier

Grows 2 to 3 studs of glowing flowers that sell for a decent price.

80,000 Sheckles

Evo Mushroom

B Tier

An Evo seed with prices ranging from 40k at Tier I to 80k at Tier IV. Its final form is multi-harvest, making it well worth snagging.

80,000 Sheckles

Pricklefruit

B Tier

In the range of 80,000 shekels per fruit. It’s reharvestable.

80,000 Sheckles

Sundew

B Tier

An uncommon seed from the Prime Seed Pack that grants two Sundews.

80,000 Sheckles

Hinomai

B Tier

A Chinese-themed botanical plant that yields one Hinomai per harvest cycle, selling for 80k.

80,000 Sheckles

Candy Sunflower

B Tier

Single harvest but brings in 80k each.

80,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Celestiberry

B Tier

Better than Grape and Pepper in both selling value and multi-harvest ability, offering more berries (approximately 8).

80,000 Sheckles

Suncoil

B Tier

Falls between Lumira and Honeysuckle in value, sitting at 80k Sheckles.

80,000 Sheckles

Feijoa

B Tier

6 Feijoa comes in one batch, with each tagged at 13k.

78,000 Sheckles

Chicken Feed

B Tier

Unlike other monstrous plants, this spooky crop is shaped like a beehive. While it sprouts one fruit on the vine, it’s not a one-time plant.

77,777 Sheckles

Hazelnut

B Tier

A nutty crop from the Nutty Chest that produces 3 to 4 Hazelnuts.

75,000 Sheckles

Briar Rose

B Tier

A plant that grows a giant rose on top, and it sells for good money.

75,000 Sheckles

Purple Dahlia

B Tier

Multi-harvest flower that produces 1 Dahlia at a time, with each selling for around 75k Sheckles.

75,000 Sheckles

Taco Fern

B Tier

It has a 75k base value, but only produces one Fern at a time.

75,000 Sheckles

Twisted Tangle

B Tier

Not the friendliest to touch (a thorny plant), but drops 3 to 4 Tangles with ease.

75,000 Sheckles

Moon Melon

B Tier

Multi-harvest plant that grants 3 to 4 melons that trade for 18k Sheckles each.

72,000 Sheckles

Black Bat Flower

B Tier

Blooms into 1 to 2 Black Bat Flowers (from Season Pass Tier 6).

70,000 Sheckles

Glowthorn

B Tier

Usually gives two Glowthorns, putting the plant somewhere in the B tier.

70,000 Sheckles

Sugarglaze

B Tier

A donut-shaped plant from the cooking event that’s pretty decent.

70,000 Sheckles

Aloe Vera

B Tier

It’s a single-harvest plant that gives a one-shot pay-out of 69k Sheckles.

69,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Horned Dinoshroom

B Tier

Like Aloe Vera in price and fruit count, but it regrows after every cycle, so better than that in this range.

69,000 Sheckles

Ember Lily

B Tier

Regrows 1 at a time for 66,600 Sheckles. Not as good as Honeysuckle, Suncoil, or Lumira.

66,600 Sheckles

Pink Lily

B Tier

Reproduces but only yields 1 flower at a time. Worth around 65k Sheckles.

65,000 Sheckles

Prickly Pear

B Tier

This plant resembles a cactus and yields 9 red prickly pears. All are tagged at 7k.

63,000 Sheckles

Acorn Squash

B Tier

A thin, stem-like plant that grows 4 Squashes (each sells for 15k).

62,220 Sheckles

Zombie Fruit

B Tier

A creepy plant that looks like a zombie hand rising from a grave. Reharvestable.

60,000 Sheckles

Starfruit

B Tier

Multi-harvest crop that spawns 4 starfruits, with each going for around 15k.

60,000 Sheckles

Jalapeno

B Tier

A cooking ingredient plant that whips up 2 to 4 jalapenos (30k each).

60,000 Sheckles

Ghoul Root

B Tier

A decent spooky crop designed like a scary creature (a creepy version of Disney’s Groot) that gives one fruit per cycle.

55,555 Sheckles

Broccoli

B Tier

The least profitable crop in Sam’s Seed Shop Tier 2, it only produces a single broccoli.

55,000 Sheckles

Bee Balm

B Tier

Spawns 3 flowers per round, with each being priced at 18k Sheckles. Can regrow.

54,000 Sheckles

Mango

B Tier

Gives a bunch of fruit just like in real life (approximately 8), and each is worth 6,500.

52,000 Sheckles

Pitcher Plant

B Tier

While it offers a similar profit to Pepper, this crop only produces 1 Pitcher Plant per round.

52,000 Sheckles

Evo Beetroot

B Tier

This seed yields only once per cycle and doesn’t regrow from Tier I to Tier III, but once transformed into its Tier IV version, it becomes reharvestable and sells for 50k.

50,000 Sheckles

Mandrake

B Tier

A plant available in the Beanstalk Event that doesn’t reproduce.

50,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Flare Daisy

B Tier

Unlike many plants before the 1.19.0 update, this uncommon one is multi-harvest and gives two flowers.

50,000 Sheckles

Paradise Petal

B Tier

2 petals spawn on the tree with a 25k general price. Also, it's a multi-harvest plant.

50,000 Sheckles

Violet Corn

B Tier

Outperforms other multi-harvest flowers like Foxglove and Succulent, with a top value of 50k.

50,000 Sheckles

Dandelion

B Tier

Like with Nectarshade, plant in bulk and wait for mutations if you want massive returns.

50,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Red Lollipop

B Tier

One-time lollipop that sells for 50k Sheckles.

50,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Rose

B Tier

A nice pick, since it grows back in bunches and sells for a hefty price when you stack the variants (5k Sheckles).

50,000 Sheckles

Nectarshade

B Tier

Should be planted in batches of at least 30 to 50 and must gain mutations like Celestial, Voidtouched, and Shocked.

50,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Carnival Pumpkin

C Tier

The first ever pumpkin plant added to GaG . You can harvest one pumpkin from it each time.

48,000 Sheckles

Cacao

C Tier

This divine crop can be harvested multiple times (up to 4), with each bringing in 12k money.

48,000 Sheckles

Loquat

C Tier

Comparable to Cacao in terms of profit, though it yields 6 loquats, each for 8k.

48,000 Sheckles

Frostspike

C Tier

A unique seed obtainable by participating in the Frozen Ice King weather; It gives one Frostspike and is multi-harvest.

45,000 Sheckles

Untold Bell

C Tier

A beautiful magic crop that gives three lilac-colored glowing fruits, one for 15k Sheckles.

45,000 Sheckles

Fall Berry

C Tier

A rare plant from the Fall Seed Pack that grows a bright maroon-colored berry ready for picking.

42,222 Sheckles

Sunbulb

C Tier

A pretty average Fairy Event crop, usually gives two Sunbulbs.

40,000 Sheckles

Pear

C Tier

One is priced at 20k Sheckles, and the plant produces 2 pears.

40,000 Sheckles

Grape

C Tier

A multi-harvest berry plant that produces 5 grapes, with each selling for 7,850.

39,250 Sheckles

Willowberry

C Tier

Pretty decent crop from Beanstalk Event Part 2, gives five berries each time.

37,500 Sheckles

Eggplant

C Tier

Gets you 3 eggplants with a selling value of 12k.

36,000 Sheckles

Lilac

C Tier

Was once close to the Beanstalk in profit, but now grows only one flower worth 35k Sheckles.

35,000 Sheckles

Lotus

C Tier

Same deal as Cursed Fruit in price and type.

35,000 Sheckles

Stonebite

C Tier

Similar to Lotus in profit, though it’s a single-use plant.

35,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Cantaloupe

C Tier

Only 1 cantaloupe spawns at a time, but the price is fairly reasonable at 34k.

34,000 Sheckles

Banesberry

C Tier

Like in real life, this plant looks like it has doll eyes beaded on it. It’s a berry plant exclusively dug up by the Bone Dog in Grow a Garden and is multi-harvest.

33,333 Sheckles

Jack O Lantern

C Tier

A reharvestable plant that yields one carved pumpkin each time.

33,333 Sheckles

Pepper

C Tier

Reharvestable veggie that grows 4 peppers at a time, with each being worth 8k.

32,000 Sheckles

Pixie Faern

C Tier

A multi-harvest crop that gives one pinkish Pixie Faren per cycle.

30,000 Sheckles

Spring Onion

C Tier

A one-time plant from the Connoisseur Event that’s valued similarly to Artichoke and Crocus from past updates.

30,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Artichoke

C Tier

One of the craftable single-harvest plants from the Cooking event.

30,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Crocus

C Tier

Sells for around 30k Sheckles, but it can’t reproduce. It's best used for pairing mutations.

30,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Horsetail

C Tier

Matches Crocus in value and harvest type.

30,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Rhubarb

C Tier

An uncommon crop that produces a pair of rhubarbs, each selling for 15k at the Shell Shop.

30,000 Sheckles

Dezen

C Tier

Looks gorgeous glowing in your plot, but it’s a one-and-done kind of plant.

29,250 Sheckles (One-time)

Moonflower

C Tier

You get 3 to 4 flowers, and each sells for 9.5k.

28,500 Sheckles

Cursed Fruit

C Tier

Same, multi-harvest, and goes for 25,750 Sheckles.

25,750 Sheckles

Autumn Shroom

C Tier

A mushroom-looking plant with an orangish, fall-like color, good for beginners to make money.

25,000 Sheckles

Emerald Bud

C Tier

From the Fairy Event expansion, it can give players one glowing bud and is reharvestable.

25,000 Sheckles

Veinpetal

C Tier

Blood-red plant with octopus-like petals, but only pops out one per round.

25,000 Sheckles

Moonglow

C Tier

Keeps producing 1 Moonglow, which then goes for 25k.

25,000 Sheckles

Manuka Flower

C Tier

Takes a lot of effort to craft, and it’s a single-harvest plant that sells for around 25k on average. It’s a profitable crop only if you’re stacking lots of variants.

25,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Lavender

C Tier

Very similar to the Manuka Flower in both price and type. It only makes sense to grow if you’re aiming to combine multiple mutations on it.

25,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Wild Carrot

C Tier

Another single-use plant that trades for 25k.

25,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Succulent

C Tier

Kind of like Foxglove, it’s a multi-harvest plant that only gives 1 flower per round, but it makes up for it with a better price, averaging at 25k.

25,000 Sheckles

Zenflare

C Tier

Like Monoblooma in price, but better since it regrows after being picked

25,000 Sheckles

Blood Banana

C Tier

A solid pick. It regrows with 4 bananas, and each one sells for 6k Sheckles.

24,000 Sheckles

Delphinium

C Tier

It offers the same 24k Sheckles profit as Blood Banana but isn’t better, since it’s not multi-harvest.

24,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Peace Lily

C Tier

Just like Delphinium in both profit and harvestability.

24,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Durian

C Tier

You get 3 fruits from it, and each goes for 7.5k.

22,500 Sheckles

Bloodred Mushroom

C Tier

A small mushroom plant that keeps growing more deep red mushrooms after each harvest.

22,222 Sheckles

Monoblooma

C Tier

It’s not a crop that produces multiple fruits, but it easily sells for 22k once picked.

22,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Foxglove

C Tier

Cultivates 1 per cycle, with a selling value of 20k Sheckles.

20,000 Sheckles

Parsley

C Tier

A stick-shaped crop with several leaves on it, sells for 20k.

20,000 Sheckles

Kiwi

C Tier

Even with 7 fruits, it doesn’t outperform Cacao, Pepper, or most B-tier plants.

19,250 Sheckles

Bell Pepper

C Tier

3 bell peppers grow from one leafy plant, with each being valued at 5.5k.

16,500 Sheckles

Soul Fruit

C Tier

Pretty much like Passionfruit in how it works and sells (7,750 each).

15,500 Sheckles

Dragon Fruit

C Tier

Grows 2 to 3 at once, with each being worth 4,750.

14,250 Sheckles

Crown Of Thorns

C Tier

A pretty average plant you can get from the Skyroot Chest.

14,000 Sheckles

Cranberry

C Tier

Players can pick 4 berries in each round, with each being worth 3.5k.

13,600 Sheckles

Fissure Berry

C Tier

A berry that disappears after picking, selling for just 13k.

13,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Coconut

C Tier

Gives 32 pieces. 1 usually goes for 400 Sheckles, but with the right mutations, it can reach millions.

12,800 Sheckles

Flare Melon

C Tier

Works like the Glowpod from the 1.20.0 update, yields one melon per harvest. It can be reharvested, but the sell value is low.

12,500 Sheckles

Turnip

C Tier

This plant makes one turnip each round and lets you harvest it again and again.

12,000 Sheckles

Chocolate Carrot

C Tier

Doesn't reproduce and is still worth 11k.

11,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Passionfruit

C Tier

Grows about 3 fruits per round, with each selling for 3,550 Sheckles.

10,650 Sheckles

Cactus

C Tier

Makes 3 cacti in one cycle that sell for 3.4k Sheckles each.

10,200 Sheckles

Onion

C Tier

An uncommon plant from the Gourmet Seed Pack that disappears after one harvest.

10,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Easter Egg

C Tier

Only worth it in mutated form. 4 eggs sold at 2.5k Sheckles per egg.

10,000 Sheckles

Glowpod

C Tier

Multi-harvest, but not as good as the Crown of Thorns from the Beanstalk Event (Part 2).

7,500 Sheckles

Calla Lily

C Tier

Somewhat like Burning Bud, with blue-white hues; reharvestable but not really profitable.

7,500 Sheckles

Banana

C Tier

Spawns 4 bananas, with each being priced at 1,750 Sheckles.

7,000 Sheckles

Mint

C Tier

Worth it when you sell the mutated versions.

5,250 Sheckles

Ferntail

C Tier

An average seed from the Chubby Chipmunk Event. Usually grows 2 Ferntails but can yield up to 3.

4,000 Sheckles

Bamboo

C Tier

It’s a one-time crop, but the mutated versions can earn you a lot.

4,000 Sheckles

Rafflesia

C Tier

It’s a one-time plant that sells for 3,500 max.

3,500 Sheckles (One-time)

Nightshade

C Tier

Just average and only usable once.

3,500 Sheckles (One-time)

Cherry Blossom

C Tier

Low value unless mutated.

3,500 Sheckles

Pumpkin

C Tier

Not reharvestable but okay value. Better with mutations.

3,400 Sheckles

Watermelon

C Tier

Only makes sense to sell when mutated.

3,000 Sheckles

Glowshroom

C Tier

Each goes for 300 Sheckles, and each plant yields 10 in total.

3,000 Sheckles

Papaya

C Tier

Produces a lot, with each going for 1,000 Sheckles.

3,000 Sheckles

Apple

C Tier

Low cost, but it's not bad early on since it gives you 10 apples in a single harvest.

2,750 Sheckles

Lemon

C Tier

Pretty much the same deal as Cherry Blossom.

2,450 Sheckles

Avocado

C Tier

From one tree, you get 6 avocados, with each fruit going for 350 Sheckles.

2,100 Sheckles

Pineapple

C Tier

Grows back again, and each sells for 2,000 Sheckles.

2,000 Sheckles

Green Apple

C Tier

A reharvestable tree that spawns 6 greenish apples. Despite their higher price of 300 Sheckles, they still fall short compared to regular apples.

1,800 Sheckles

Peach

C Tier

Works fine if you're planning to sell the mutated version.

1,800 Sheckles

Daffodil

C Tier

Same as Orange Tulip.

1,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Raspberry

D Tier

One tile gives 9 raspberries, but each is only priced at 00.

900 Sheckles

Orange Tulip

D Tier

A one-time crop that doesn't bring much value.

850 Sheckles (One-time)

Blueberry

D Tier

Regrows with 7 berries but makes very little money.

140 Sheckles

Tomato

D Tier

Tomato trees can produce 4 fruits in one go.

120 Sheckles

Strawberry

D Tier

Only worth planting if you’ve got nothing better.

60 Sheckles

Cauliflower

D Tier

Pretty useless unless you're low on cash or there’s an event asking for it.

50 Sheckles

Corn

D Tier

Super low value.

40 Sheckles

Carrot

D Tier

Not reharvestable and sells cheap.

20 Sheckles (One-time)

The profit you get from each plant can also depend on the size and weight of its fruits . Some crops may be better than others if they consistently grow heavier-than-average fruits. For example, Moon Mango has a lower base profit than Maple Apple but often grows big fruits, meaning it can end up earning more than its listed value.

Best Plants for Stacking Mutations in Grow a Garden

While the tier list above ranks crops by overall value, some GaG plants may have lower total profitability, but higher base value per fruit, making them ideal for stacking mutations. By combining mutations from weather effects, pets, and tools, you can turn their worth into the trillions.

Best Plants for Stacking Mutations

Base Price

Avg Fruit Count

Crimson Thorn

210,000 Sheckles

7 to 8

Bone Blossom

200,000 Sheckles

4 to 5

Maple Resin

190,000 Sheckles

6 to 7

Cocomango

180,000 Sheckles

4 to 5

M ultitrap

180,000 Sheckles

3

Wispwing

180,000 Sheckles

1

Evo Apple (IV)

165,000 Sheckles

4

Sunflower

160,000 Sheckles

1

Weeping Branch

155,555 Sheckles

3 to 4

Naval Wort

150,000 Sheckles

4

Firewell

112,111 Sheckles

2 to 3

Poison Apple

111,111 Sheckles

4 to 5

Candy Blossom

100,000 Sheckles

12

Auburn Pine

73,555 Sheckles

4

Moon Mango

50,000 Sheckles

13 to 20

Special fruits like Bone Blossoms can also become massive using the Sprinkler method , which further increases their selling price.

Best Seeds in Grow a Garden

Here’s a quick look at the must-have plants in Grow a Garden :

  • The Crimson Thorn seed is part of the current meta in GaG . It produces lots of premium units, making them great for selling directly, and even better when mutated to boost profits further.
  • Candy Blossom and Maple Resin are also among the best seeds in Grow a Garden right now. Candy Blossom has been popular since the early updates, while Maple Resin gained attention after the Fall update. A single harvest from either sells for a huge amount.
  • Bone Blossom and Moon Mango rank among the top 7 plants in the tier list. Bone Blossom can grow 5 fruits, while the Mango tree can produce up to 20 at once. If not, replanting with the Reclaimer is always a solid option.
  • Among Tier 1 seeds in the Seed Shop, Sugar Apple comes right after Crimson Thorn. It’s a strong non-event plant, but Cocomango from Tier 2 outshines it in both price and profit, you just have to grind a bit to unlock it.
  • Finally, in the 1.28.0 update , Weeping Branch is definitely worth grinding. It’s profitable and has a passive like Amber, making closeby plants go through three mutation cycles: Wilted (10x), Withered (20x), and Desolate (50x).
447
8.8 /10

Roblox

WHERE TO PLAY

Powered by

item.title: Upcoming Games Like Skyrim
item.description:
Summary

  • Multiple upcoming action-RPGs promise Skyrim-like medieval fantasy, brutal combat, and vast exploration.
  • Highlights include The Witcher 4, Fable, Crimson Desert, and darker, first-person titles like Fatekeeper.
  • Many releases lack firm dates; expect 2026 launches and Xbox Game Pass entries, plus dark, brutal tones.

Skyrim is the right combination of medieval fantasy and action RPG that lots of players enjoy. Especially those looking for incredible adventures and brutal combat. However, those who have done roaming around the north of Tamriel are thinking about what comes next.

Here is a list of upcoming games that, like Skyrim, are going to deliver similar experiences for those looking for thrilling action, dangerous creatures to beat, and convoluted story plots based on political struggles and the change of eras.

7 The Witcher 4

The Wiedźmin Saga Continues

The Witcher 4
Action RPG
Open-World
Developer(s)
CD Projekt Red

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Publisher(s)
CD Projekt Red
Franchise
The Witcher
Powered by

The Witcher 4 will mark a new beginning for the series originally written by Andrzej Sapkowski, and brought to the gaming universe by CD Projekt Red. And fans couldn't be happier about the return of one of the main characters of the series, this time, as the sole protagonist of this story, which already promises to be even darker than Geralt's tale of sword and sorcery.

It might not be a game that can be played in First Person, like Skyrim, but it has all the ingredients of medieval dark fantasy, magic, and brutal combat needed to satisfy those looking to explore the most dangerous forests and seek monsters to slay. Sadly, The Witcher 4 doesn't have a release date yet.

6 Fable

A New Beginning For The Acclaimed Series

Fable
Action RPG
Adventure
Systems
Released
2026

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Developer(s)
Playground Games
Publisher(s)
Xbox Game Studios
Franchise
Fable
Powered by

Based on the original series created by the legend Peter Molineaux and his team at Lionhead Studios, Fable is a new beginning for this story of heroes and villains in the magical world of Albion. This time, it's being developed by Playground Games and Xbox Game Studios, and that is bound to bring changes to the soul of the project.

However, that doesn't mean it's going to be less fun or immersive, since for all the devs have showcased so far, it respects most of the core elements of the original series: a sword and sorcery, enemies that look like a mishmash between a Grimm Brother's character and something out of our worst nightmares, and a witty sense of humor accompanying the heroes (or villains) through their journey across beautiful scenarios. Fable will be released at an unconfirmed date in 2026.

5 The Blood of Dawnwalker

Warrior By Day, Bloody Avenger By Night

The Blood of Dawnwalker
RPG
Action
Adventure
Systems
Developer(s)
Rebel Wolves

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Publisher(s)
Bandai Namco Studios
Powered by

Born of a studio that combines veterans of the game industry (mostly former CD Projekt Red employees), The Blood of Dawnwalker is an original story that combines gothic horror with medieval fantasy. Its dark mood and setting already point in the direction of games like Skyrim, The Witcher 3, and Dark Souls.

However, the little gameplay footage and teasers showcase a strain of stealth and guerrilla combat, which is also a nice touch. Apparently, players will incarnate a half-human / half-vampire as he seeks to rescue his family from the claws of a supernatural enemy (with a real-time countdown and all). Players might have to alternate the human gameplay with vampire mode play to accomplish their goal, but the question remains: Will it be enough to satisfy the taste for blood of most Skyrim players? We will know once it's released in 2026, at an unconfirmed date.

4 Crimson Desert

The Waiting Is Almost Over

Crimson Desert
Action-Adventure
Systems
Released
March 19, 2026

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

Platform(s)
PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X and Series S, Microsoft Windows
Powered by

Since its original announcement back in 2019, Crimson Desert has been in development by Pearl Abyss, and players were biting their nails, waiting for an exact release date. Recently, the developers of Black Desert confirmed that the long-awaited Single-Player Action RPG, is going to be released on March 16, 2026.

For those looking to battle dangerous enemies in a medieval fantasy setting, this game will offer a chance to enjoy non-stop, fluid combat in third person that merges the best of games like The Witcher 3 and Dark Souls, with the characteristic combo system of Black Desert. With combat actions that go from bull rushes, shield slams, and even powerful dropkicks, the game will offer a wide array of ways to kill enemies. The graphics will be top-notch, too, so Skyrim players can expect lots of cool views and a vast wilderness to explore.

3 Clockwork Revolution

A SteamPunk Fallout/Skyrim Merge

Clockwork Revolution
RPG
Steampunk
First-Person
Action
Systems
Developer(s)
inXile entertainment

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Publisher(s)
Xbox Game Studios
Platform(s)
PC, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
Powered by

With a design style that takes the best from games like Fallout , Dishonored , and Skyrim , this Steam Punk adventure is all about taking arms against an evil regime. Players will be fighting alongside a group of misfits against an evil regime, and possibly, changing the course of history in the process.

One of the coolest characteristics that can be appreciated about Clockwork Revolution, is its weapon crafting system, which is very similar to that of Fallout, but it has its own quirks and, of course, steampunk-style contraptions to craft and use to kill everything that moves. This game is set to be released on an unconfirmed date, though it is known that it's going to be available on Xbox Game Pass.

2 Fatekeeper

A Brutal First Person Fantasy RPG

First shown in THQ Nordic's Digital Showcase back in August 2025, Fatekeeper is one of the many games that hopes to inherit Skyrim's title of the next-generation first-person fantasy action RPG. Alongside titles like Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon, it is set in a much darker medieval-fantasy universe, only this time, it will probably have the characteristic THQ imprint that has brought to life many great action titles like Titan Ques t (and most recently Titan Quest 2 ).

Fatekeeper's focus seems to be more on the side of combat and magic, with a linear storyline and tighter (not open-world) gameplay experience. For what has been showcased so far, it looks like a mixture of the classic Might and Magic games and a Souls-like. Quite intriguing, and definitely among the wishlist of many Skyrim fans.

1 Alkahest

An Alchemist Working His Way Up In A Dark And Unforgiving World

Alkahest is one of the most promising upcoming games that mixes first-person combat and a fantasy environment in a medieval world. With a fully destructive environment as part of the combat experience to boot. This game is being developed by HypeTrain Digital (developers of Voidtrain and The Wild Eight ), so it's a studio with lots of experience that has put lots of interesting games in the market.

Skyrim fans should be looking up to Alkahest , and though we don't have a disclosed date of release yet, it looks promising enough to make up for the wait.
